name: (2E)-[(3-methylphenyl)hydrazono][4-(4-methylphenyl)-1,3-thiazol-2-yl]ethanenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1236

name: (2E)-[(3-methylphenyl)hydrazono][4-(4-methylphenyl)-1,3-thiazol-2-yl]ethanenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1236
Reason: The compound has several functional groups that influence its melting point: aromatic rings, a nitrile group, azo bond (N=N), a thiazole ring, and methyl groups. Benzene, as a basic aromatic unit, has a melting point of 5.5 °C. Aromatic rings typically increase melting points due to strong pi-pi interactions, with ++10 per ring approx. Nitrile groups are polar and can contribute to both dipole-dipole interactions and potential hydrogen bonding with the N-H of the azo bond, giving ++15. The azo bond (N=N) itself is associated with conjugation and rigidity in the structure, providing ++25. A thiazole ring has nitrogen and sulfur atoms which can contribute to dipole-dipole interactions and potential aromaticity, giving ++20. Methyl groups add hydrophobic character and slightly increase the molecular weight, giving ++5 per methyl group.
Prediction: Benzene basic unit (5.5) + Aromatic rings (2 x 10) + Nitrile group (15) + Azo bond (25) + Thiazole ring (20) + Methyl groups (2 x 5) = 5.5 + 20 + 15 + 25 + 20 + 10 = 95.5
